prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The line survey carried out with the SMA towards Arp 220 in the 1.2mm atmospheric line reached an rms of 30-50 mJy/beam in 5.1~MHz (~6 km/s) channels. With ALMA Cycle 3 we aim to push down this sensitivity by a factor of ~10 and at a spatial resolution one order of magnitude better. We aim to reach an homogeneous rms across the band 3 of 0.8~mJy, assuming a channel spacing of 20~\,km\,s$^{-1}$. This sensitivity, equivalent to 0.4-0.5 K for the 0.5" beam, aims at getting close to those of our Cycle 1 Band 6 and 7 observations (2 mJy ~ 0.1-0.2 K), keeping a reasonable integration time. To achieve that goal we will need an integration of ~20 min on source for each frequency setup. Note that this increase in sensitivity request doubles the integration on source, but has little impact on overall time request which is dominated by calibration and overheads.
We note that ALMA will reach the confusion limit in most of the frequencies covered. Thus larger integrations, resulting in more efficient observations, would not provide any extra meaningful information. However, the narrower linewidths (in frequency) in Band 3 and 4 justifies the enhanced sensitivity request.
On the other hand, such deep survey would be impossible within a reasonable time in any other interferometer.

Given the 500 km/s wide emission lines in Arp 220 we use the FDM spectral setup covering 1.875 GHz. We apply an spectral averaging of 8 channels down to a resolution of 12 km/s, enough to resolve the lines.
The spectral bands have been configured with an overlap of 100 MHz between SPW within a baseband. Among the different SG, the overlap is also of 100 MHz.
Frequency centers are defined in sky frequency, with source velocity set to 0, to have an accurate control on the SPW overlaps.

We aim to achieve an angular resolution of 0.5'' which is enough to resolve the two nuclei of Arp 220 separated by ~1''. The extended emission observed in the source across a region of 3'' is small enough to be recovered by the 12 m array, so ACA observations are not required. Our Cycle 1 observations showed the snapshot capabilities required, where short integrations provide enough UV coverage to minimize sidelobes in the central ~5'' where the emission of Arp 220 is concentrated.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Cycle1_Band6low4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This SG is a copy from Cycle 1 project 2012.1.00453.S. Thus it is only to be observed if not completed during the rest of Cycle 2.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The line survey carried out with the SMA towards Arp 220 in the 1.2mm atmospheric line reached an rms of 30-50 mJy/beam in 5.1~MHz (~6 km/s) channels. With ALMA Cycle 3 we aim to push down this sensitivity by a factor of ~10 and at a spatial resolution one order of magnitude better. We aim to reach an homogeneous rms across the whole spectral scan of 2~mJy, assuming a channel spacing of 20~\,km\,s$^{-1}$. This sensitivity aims at matching our Cycle 1 Band 6 and 7 observations To achieve that goal we will need an integration of ~5 min on source for each frequency setup.
We note that ALMA will reach the confusion limit in most of the frequencies covered. Thus larger integrations, resulting in more efficient observations, would not provide any extra meaningful information. On the other hand, such deep survey would be impossible within a reasonable time in any other interferometer.

Given the 500 km/s wide emission lines in Arp 220 we use the FDM spectral setup covering 1.875 GHz. We apply an spectral averaging of 8 channels down to a resolution of 12 km/s, enough to resolve the lines.
The spectral bands have been configured with an overlap of 100 MHz between SPW within a baseband. Among the different SG, the overlap is also of 100 MHz.
Frequency centers are defined in sky frequency, with source velocity set to 0, to have an accurate control on the SPW overlaps.

We aim to achieve an angular resolution of 0.5'' which is enough to resolve the two nuclei of Arp 220 separated by ~1''. The extended emission observed in the source across a region of 3'' is small enough to be recovered by the 12 m array, so ACA observations are not required. Our Cycle 1 observations showed the snapshot capabilities required, where short integrations provide enough UV coverage to minimize sidelobes in the central ~5'' where the emission of Arp 220 is concentrated.

The line survey carried out with the SMA towards Arp 220 in the 1.2mm atmospheric line reached an rms of 30-50 mJy/beam in 5.1~MHz (~6 km/s) channels. With ALMA Cycle 3 we aim to push down this sensitivity by a factor of ~10 and at a spatial resolution one order of magnitude better. Thus larger integrations, resulting in more efficient observations, would not provide any extra meaningful information. On the other hand, such deep survey would be impossible within a reasonable time in any other interferometer.

Given the 500 km/s wide emission lines in Arp 220 we use the FDM spectral setup covering 1.875 GHz. We apply an spectral averaging of 8 channels down to a resolution of 12 km/s, enough to resolve the lines.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Molecular spectroscopy is shown to be a good probe of the heating mechanism in heavily obscured nuclei. Though extensively observed, the closest ULIRG prototype Arp220 continues to surprise us at high resolution mm/submm (Tunnard+2015,Rangwala+2015,Aalto+2015). Our still ongoing Cycle 1 project to explore the chemistry of Arp220 at high resolution reached the confusion limit and isolated the chemistry of the two nuclei. First results are being published. We unveiled the rich chemistry of each nucleus, with differences both to local galaxies and between nuclei. The faintest species (some complex ones) are emitted in regions with different excitation conditions. Thus, a full picture of the physical morphology of its two nuclei requires more accurate determination of molecular abundances and of the excitation conditions of each detected species. This motivates us to extend the survey towards the lower frequencies to increase the number of transitions and energy ranges covered. This survey will provide a basic tamplete, not only for future studies of Arp220 but for all kinds of IR luminous galaxies near and far. If Band 6 setups are observed in Cycle 2 the time request will be 6.4h.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00453.S, Spatially resolved wide band spectroscopy in ULIRG obscured nuclei, Sergio Martin
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica
Earth and Space Sciences, Chalmers University of Technology
Onsala Space Observatory, Chalmers University of Technology
IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
University College London, London, University of
Observatorio de Madrid, Observatorio Astronomico Nacional
Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica
